Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Discussing Solutions and Strategies

You can start the Summarize after all have finished exploring What If...? Situation B. Those who finish What If...? Situation B before others can work on What If...? Situation C and help lead the discussion for those who did not get to it.

  • Begin by having students share how they used the table of ratios to answer the questions about the cosots for different numbers of boxes. Seeing the various ways others use multiplicative reasoning can enhance each student's flexibility to reason with ratios. (Language)
  • Teaching Aid 2.2: Selling Cupcakes Ratio Table can be used as needed to illustrate ideas from students.
    • How can you use the table to find the cost for 20 boxes?
Answers will vary. See some possible strategies that follow.

Strategy 1

Students double the 10 boxes to get 20 boxes and double the prices of $120 to $240.

This is scaling the ratio using multiplicative reasoning. This is one example of finding equivalent ratios using proportional reasoning.

Strategy 2

Students find the cost for 1 box using division. Then they multiply the number of boxes by 20 and the cost by 20.

This is unit rate reasoning that will be made more explicit in Investigation 3.

Strategy 3

Students add the 5 boxes and the 25 boxes together to get 20 boxes. Then they ass the $60 ad the $180 together to get $240 for the 20 boxes.

While students might think of this as addition, we can also look at the reasoning using the Distributive Proprty. Five of the 12-dollar boxes and 15 of the 12-dollar boxes is the same as 20 of the 12-dfollar boxes. 5($12) + 15($12) = 20($12)
